name: heat production, air-water heat pump 10kW | heat, air-water heat pump 10kW | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/561/documentation

This dataset represents the production of heat with an air-water heat pump for an average one family house in Europe. The dataset is based on a heat pump unit operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions. The air-water heat pump has a heat capacity of 10 kW and a Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) of 2.8 (for the year 1998). For this dataset the infrastructure of a brine-water heat pump with 10 kW is used. Differences in infrastructure between the two types of heat pumps are considered by a scaling factor. Data for the estimation of SPF is based on a field study for Swiss heat pumps an on various literature. Life time is assumed to be 20 years. This dataset is based on the following reference values: for the average one maily house a heating requirement of 10 kW, a heat distribution system (low-temperature system) of 50/40°C and a heat supply of approximately 20.000 kWh with 2.000 operating hours were assumed. The system is assumed to be operated without an auxiliary heating system. ;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From ambient air entering the heat pump. 

This activity ends with heat at the air-water heat pump unit with a life time of 20 years. This dataset includes emissions of refrigerant R134a during operation and the UCTE electricity mix. This dataset doesn´t include the heat distribution in the one family house nor a buffer heat storage.
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is based on a heat pump unit operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Air-water heat pumps use ambient air as heat source. Here water represents the heating-circuit water. Most of the heat pumps in Switzerland are operated in a monovalent way, i.e. even at low outdoor temperatures the heat pump provides enough heat and an auxiliary system is not necessary if buildings are well insulated and a low temperature heating system is used. Air-water heat pumps are often used for retrofitting the heating system. When retrofitting heating systems in old buildings, special conditions have to be considered. Usually the heat distribution system in old buildings is operated with higher temperatures than in new buildings. For this purpose, particular retrofit heat pumps were developed. Seasonal Performance factors for retrofit heat pumps (air-water) and Swiss conditions are estimated to range between 2.5 and 2.7.;;;The Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) is an important figure which indicates the ratio between heat amount at heat pump (respectively at storage if available) and specific demand for electricity of the heat pump (incl. all common auxiliaries). ;;New geothermal heat pumps in Europe achieve Seasonal Performance Factors of 4 or even higher. This is due to improved components and lower temperatures in the distribution system (below 35°C) based on improved heat insulation. ;;The Seasonal Performance Factors are estimated, based on a comprehensive field study for heat pump installations in Switzerland. For this dataset a SPF of 2,8 for air-water heat pumps operated in Switzerland in the year 1998 was assumed.;;References:;Zogg, Martin (2002b): The Swiss Retrofit Heat Pump Programme. Proceedings of the 7th International Energy Agency Conference on Heat Pumping Technologies, Beijing, China, May 19-22, 2002.;;Erb M and Hubacher P: Field analysis of Swiss heat pump installations. IEA Heat Pump Centre Newsletter. Volume 19 - No. 1/2001. Available from: www.heatpumpcentre.org
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is based on an air-water heat pump with a heat capacity of 10 kW operated in Switzerland and extrapolated to European conditions.

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Operating hours of 2000 h/a and a life time of 20 years are assumed for the air-water heat pump. The reciprocal value indicates the amount of heat pumps required to produce one MJ of useful heat.
EcoSpold01Location=RER

flow.name: heat, air-water heat pump 10kW
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description:
Estimation. For the calculation of the air-water heat pump the infrastructure of a brine-water heat pump with 10 kW is used.  Thus, differences in infrastructure between the two types of heat pumps are considered by a scaling factor. 

The main difference between brine-water and air-water heat pumps lies in the Seasonal Performance Factor and borehole heat exchanger, which in case of the air-water heat pump does not exist. 

Air-water heat pumps have a higher total weight than brine-water heat pumps. (Frischknecht 1999, WPZ 2003). The weight of the air-water heat pump in Frischknecht is assumed to be 173 kg, which would relate to 250 kg for a heat pump with a thermal capacity of 10 kW (compared to 130 kg of weight for the brine-water heat pump with a thermal capacity of 10 kW). The weight of air-water heat pumps can be up to 300 kg. The higher weight of the air-water heat pump is mainly due to the heavy condenser. (ELCOPLUS 2002)

Furthe references:

Wärmepumpen-Testzentrum Winterthur-Töss. Testliste. Stand April 2003. <http://www.wpz.ch/>

ELCOPLUS. Technische Dokumentation Wärmepumpen aerotop. März 2002.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description:
Estimation. The UCTE electricity mix is used. Data is based on the infrastrucutre of brine-water heat pumps. Differences are considered with a scaling factor. Seasonal Performance Factor of 2.8 (in the year 1998, for operation in Switzerland) is estimated. The reciprocal value of the Seasonal Performance Factor (SPF) indicates the required amount of electricity in MJ per MJ of heat, at heat pump (divided by the factor of 3.6 to convert into kWh).
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description:
Estimation. Air-water heat pumps have higher filling quantities of refrigerant than brine-water heat pumps. (Frischknecht 1999, WPZ 2003)The filling quantity of refrigerant R134a amounts to approximately 0,49 kg/kW at operating conditions A2/W35 (WPZ 2003), i.e. about a factor of 1,6 higher than the amount used for brine-water heat pumps. This corresponds in proportion to data given in Frischknecht, where 2 kg of refrigerant were used for a brine-water heat pump (7 kW) and 3 kg of refrigerant were used for an air-water heat pump (7 kW).  

Further references:

Wärmepumpen-Testzentrum Winterthur-Töss. Testliste. Stand April 2003. <http://www.wpz.ch/>
EcoSpold01Location=RER

exchanges.description: Estimation. During operation leakage losses occur, which result in refrigerant emissions to air. Data is based on refrigerant losses of brine-water heat pumps. Air-water heat pumps have higher filling quantities, thus higher emissions than brine-water heat pumps. Differences are considered with a scaling factor of 1,6. 2000 h/a of operating hours are assumed.
